discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
While mashups can be useful in some cases, they are not ideal for large volumes of data due to performance, external dependency and scalability limitations. In your case, it is better to use tools such as Apex Callouts, External Objects or more robust data integrations to ensure better performance, reliability and scalability in managing invoices and other customer-related data.
So, I think that Writing an Apex callout and using it to pull data from the on-premise billing system is the most effective solution for ensuring that the sales team has access to real-time, up-to-date customer and invoice data within Salesforce. This approach minimizes the need for manual data updates and ensures that users have a seamless experience directly within Salesforce.

Selected Answer: D

What are the three considerations that a data architect should weigh before implementing this requirement? (Choose three.)

choices.D: Ensure the data is CRM-centric and able to populate standard or custom objects.
choices.E: A selection of the tool required to replicate the data.
choices.A: Ensure there is a tight relationship between order data and an enterprise resource planning (ERP) application.

discussion.content:

Tool analysis would happen at a later stage, BCD are correct.

C. Consider whether the data is required for sales reports, dashboards, and KPIs.

questions.question_text:
Universal Containers has millions of cases and are running out storage. Some user groups need to have access to historical cases for up to seven years.
Which two solutions should a data architect recommend in order to minimize performance and storage issues? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Leverage Salesforce Privacy Center to archive case data and view archived cases through an external object.
choices.A: Export data out of Salesforce and store in flat files on external system.
choices.C: Create a custom object to store case history and run reports on it.
choices.D: Leverage big objects to archive case data and Lightning components to show archived data.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
Privacy center deals with security and privacy of data, not with archiving it. So option B is unlikely to be correct. 
C - doesn't solve the issue of storage, since the data remains un-archived stored in the org.
D - is a solid option
A - although not an obvious choice, but satisfies the requirements if the data access does not have to happen from inside salesforce. Since flat files can be accessed - i guess that means the requirement is satisfied.

questions.question_text:
United Containers (UC) has released a new disaster recovery (DR) policy that states that cloud solutions need a business continuity plan in place separate from the cloud provider's built-in data recovery solution.
Which solution should a data architect use to comply with the DR policy?

choices.D: Write a custom batch Job to extract data changes nightly, and store on an external protected system.
choices.C: Leverage Salesforce weekly exports, and store data in flat files on a protected system.
choices.A: Leverage a third-party tool that extracts Salesforce data/metadata, and stores the information in an external protected system.
choices.B: Utilize an ETL tool to migrate data to an on-premise archival solution.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A - the right answer
B - not a dedicated backup solution. does not support metadata back-ups and automations
C - not often enough, a week worth of lost data is lot. Also does not support incremental changes of real-time data
D - too much development, there is a solution available on app exchange

choices.C: Create custom fields on opportunity, and copy data from order into those custom fields and run all reports on Opportunity object.
choices.B: Extract opportunity and order data from Salesforce, and use a third-party reporting tool to run reports outside of Salesforce.
choices.D: Create an aggregate custom object that summarizes the monthly and yearly values into the required format for the required reports.
choices.A: Create a skinny table in Salesforce, and copy order and opportunity fields into the skinny table and create the required reports on it.
